I have prepared a rope for you to scale the walls—I'll be ready to receive you on the other side, and help you to descend. I have also a suit of sailor's clothes for your disguise—the lugger lies ready to take us over to Holland— there we shall live happy and contented.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: I dare not agree to this. Tempt me no further—I have already refused my father's prayers.

sp.speaker: Laud.
sp.p: If you refuse me, on the word of a man, by my own hands I'll end my wretched being.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: William, is this your reformation?

sp.speaker: Laud.
sp.p: I mean it! This night decides my fate. Either you are free, or I am dead. Do not hesitate. We'll fly—far, far away. The whole study of my future life shall be to atone for the past. Margaret, if you still love me, consent, embraces her—she wavers. Think of my misery—of the injustice of your punishment. Why should you suffer for another's wickedness? Summon your courage, and liberate yourself.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: I shall never scale those walls.

sp.speaker: Laud.
sp.p: You will—you've a bold heart Hold firmly by the rope—I will cast it over. Everything favours us—the night dark, and the Governor from the jail. You will try—

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: It will be for your sake, not mine.

div.stage: Re-enter Jailor, L.

sp.speaker: Jailor.
sp.p: Come, you must take your leave. We are going to lock up for the night.

sp.speaker: Laud.
sp.p: aside. Contrive to slip back—the rope will be ready in a few minutes. Good night, sister ! aside. Remember—if you do not come, I am a dead man.

div.stage: Exit L. U. E.—Jailor locking door after him.

sp.speaker: Jailor.
sp.p: I'll fasten the inner cells, then attend to you, Margaret.

div.stage: Exit, through one of the arches, R.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: I know William's temper too well to doubt his resolution. He must be saved, even if I am lost!

div.stage: Hastens after Jailor—a door is heard to close—a bar falls, and key turns.
Music.—Margaret re-enters hurriedly with keys—locks the arch door.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: I have secured him in the inner cells ! a rope falls into the yard, a large stone being attached to it. The rope ! I must not shrink. Minutes—seconds, are more valuable than years now ! the rope is drawn up, hanging just the length of the walls inside —Margaret seizes it. my life and safety hangs on a thread !

div.stage: Ascends the rope, by placing her feet against the wall—she reaches the summit, where the spike is broken. Just as she does so, the report of a pistol is heard without—she screams, and sinks on one knee on the wall. Lights appear at windows—the prison bell rings rapidly—noise of voices heard without, and cries of "Murder!" "Ladders!" "A prisoner escaped!" The doors are opened, R., and Several Men run in with lights—they see Margaret's situation—some fetch a ladder—Persons ascend from the exterior—she is assisted down fainting, just as Will Laud is carried in, wounded, L. U. E.—Margaret rushes to him—the Crowd, Officers, &c., group around.

sp.speaker: Laud.
sp.p: I am slain!

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Who—who did this cruel deed ? kneeling by him.

sp.speaker: Laud.
sp.p: Ben Luff fired at me, and fled. Don't grieve for me. A few minutes, and all's over—say you forgive me, and I die content.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Oh, yes—yes! weeping.

sp.speaker: Laud.
sp.p: That's my brave girl. Give me air—don't leave me. extends his hand. Here—here—I want you—Margaret—hullo —where are you ?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Here—here !

sp.speaker: Laud.
sp.p: Ha, ha! so you are! What ship ahoy? Stand to your guns, lads! King's colours! Drop your mainsail! We'll meet 'em like Britons! Steady! take your aim ! fire! huzza! huzza ! shudders. Oh Margaret—bless—bless me with your voice! Forgive—forgive—

div.stage: Falls dead—she sinks on the body—Persons on the walls &c. Tableau.

div.head: ACT III.

SCENE I.—Australia. A tract of rude uncultivated country— in the centre stands a hut composed of leaves, branches, skins, logs—it is open to the Audience—the only furniture is a seaman's chest, A net hanging from the roof extended, and a hammock slung in which is Pip, with a large cap of skins—he is very pale~ Sally is sitting on the chest, with a large stick in her hand— there is a hole in the roof

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.p: Oh, mercy—oh, dear!

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: Oh, don't " oh dear " there! Get up and help me to kill the snakes and frogs. We shall be swallowed alive presently. Ugh—(screaming.) there's an ugly toad a making faces at me. (strikes with her stick )

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.p: Sarves me right for immigrating. What business had I with New South Wales ? Old England was big enough for me. It's all your own fault.

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: My fault! you wretch, you would come.

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.p: 'Cos you and that infernal Pegs made me. Nothing seems to hurt him. He says being eat up by the savages is nothing when you're used to it. Oh dear! my head !

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: You haven't the heart of a shrimp. Mr. Pegs is a gentleman—

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.p:
Why don't he pay me what he owes me, then ? there's his passage money, and his eating. When we landed, didn't he persuade us to take to the bush, as he called it—to trade with
the blackamoors—and a nice trade it is. We've been robbed and starved !

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: Pip, you're a fool!

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.p: I know I am—for being here—I'd sooner be In Margaret Catchpole's place. She's taken care of, though she be a prisoner.

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: (screams.) Oh, lor! there's a great black thing stinging me. (jumps about.) Come and catch it, Pip !

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.p: Not if I know it—he may catch I, perhaps.

div.stage: Pegs runs on, l., hid in a mantle of kangaroo's shin, carrying fruit, birds, and melons—Sally screams and clings to the hammock—Pip calls " Murder ! "—Pegs laughs.

sp.speaker: Pegs.
sp.p: Hush, my dear frionds—it's only I. (showing his head.) I found this kangaroo skin in the wood—it's what the savages use to trap birds—I've borrowed it for the same purpose. Light the fire, and let's have a feast.

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.p: Oh, yes! I can't eat poll parrots.

sp.speaker: Pegs.
sp.p: Mrs. P., perhaps you'll pick a bit, or would you relish a delicate snake better, (producing snake.)

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: (screams.) Take it away, or I shall go off!

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.p: I wish you would—for ever!

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: I shall never be comfortable again—this place'll kill me. I'm a martyred woman.

sp.speaker: Pegs.
sp.p: Let's hope not. You don't enjoy yourself. It's a glorious country—hunting, shooting, fishing—anything you want.

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.p: But eating, drinking, and lodging.

sp.speaker: Pegs.
sp.p: Magnificent country!

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: What's the use of the country when there's nothing in it ? we're worse off than Robinson Crusoe!

sp.speaker: Pegs.
sp.p: Things will improve as we go further. Who knows but some black princess may take a fancy to me—marry, and make a Prince of Wales of me.

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.p: And, perhaps her father may take a fancy to I, and make a mouthful of me!

sp.speaker: Pegs.
sp.p: You're not made for travelling.

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.p: I ain't made for eating.

div.stage: (a distant shout of the Natives heard, l.)

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: What's that—wild beastes ?

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.p: I be a dead man ! I shall never see my mother no more—oh!

sp.speaker: Pegs.
sp.p: Hush! hush! I'll look out.

div.stage: (climbs up and pops his head through the roof.)

sp.speaker: Pips.
sp.p: Tell 'em, Sally, if you can't get back, that I was swallowed up alive.

sp.speaker: Pegs.
sp.p: It's the natives coming down upon us—all armed and painted—they mean mischief.

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: Oh, mercy—mercy! I am a poor lost creature— mercy !

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.p: You don't deserve any for coming to foreign parts. I'm an innocent lamb led to the slaughter.

sp.speaker: Pegs.
sp.p: Quarrelling's no use now. Let us try to save ourselves. You lie still in the hammock—hide your head I'll take your wife on the roof—they mayn't find us there—if you stir, you're a dead man.

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.p: But they're sure to find me:

div.stage: (noise of Savages nearer, L.)

sp.speaker: Pegs.
sp.p: They're near us! not a word—come—

div.stage: Music.—He ascends first, then assists Sally to climb on the roof —a loud yell, and a party of Natives, armed with long spears—their bodies painted like skeletons, enter L.—they pause a moment.

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.p: (peeping.) They're all living skeletons! (hides his head. —the Natives eat fruit, and throw all the things about—they dance on finding the kangaroo skin, and utter a loud yell.) That chap's found his skin, (they search the hut, using violent action —swing hammock—some run their spears into it—one jumps into the chest, throws out all the things—others put them on—they dance a moment, when a gun is heard firing—they all listen— shake their spears, and rush out with a yell.—Music,—looking out.) I'm digged through and through—oh, lor!

sp.speaker: Pegs.
sp.p: (peeping in.) Is all right?

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.p: No, it' s all wrong. I shall never sit down any more— oh!

sp.speaker: Pegs.
sp.p: (to Sally.) We may come down.

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.p: Are they gone? If they'd only fell in love with me— oh me! (a Native steals cautiously back—Pip sees him, and hides his face—Pegs watches—the Native examines, but gives hammock another thrust with his spear—it shakes violently—then approaches chest, jumps in, and is stooping, when Pegs unfastens the net, which is suspended from the roof, and it falls over him— Pegs jumps down, takes spear, and keeps him in it.)

sp.speaker: Pegs.
sp.p: Huzza! I've caught him alive—the black rascal! Ah —would you ? (Sally descends.)

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.p: (jumping from his hammock.) Let's kill him, and stuff him for a curiosity ! (laughs.) Ha, ha, Mister! (snatches spear, and runs into the net—Native yells.) How do you like it, eh? Ha, ha! (All laugh—Native struggles—Pegs drags him in net, Pip poking him with spear—closed in by)

div.head: SCENE II.—A Chamber in the House of Mrs. Palmer, at Sydney.
div.stage: Enter Mrs. Palmer, R. in conversation with John Barry, altered in his appearance.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: Your request for a person to superintend your house and home comes very fortunate, Mr. Barry. I have now under my care—placed so by Government—a most useful, well conducted young woman. She arrived a prisoner, sentenced for life in the last ship from England.

sp.speaker: Barry.
sp.p: What age is she ?

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: About twenty-five. There are many remarkable circumstances connected with her sad history.

sp.speaker: Barry.
sp.p: Has she been guilty of very depraved crimes? for even in this land where we can't be over scrupulous, I should not like to receive a thoroughly wicked person.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: From the letters I received with her—written by respectable persons in England—her sins, have been from the head, not the heart. Misplaced affections have been the cause of all her misfortunes. Since she came here her conduct has been most exemplary. She is from Suffolk.

sp.speaker: Barry.
sp.p: Suffolk! What part?

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: Ipswich.

sp.speaker: Barry.
sp.p: Her name ?

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: Margaret Catchpole.

sp.speaker: Barry.
sp.p: (starts.) Margaret! here in this distant land—a— a—felon! (shudders.) What is her crime? tell me quickly, I entreat.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: Horse stealing, and attempt to escape from prison with her lover—a smuggler. He was shot, and the poor girl sentenced to transportation for life. Mr. Barry, you appear ill—do you know her?

sp.speaker: Barry.
sp.p: Know her ! She was my first, my only love. As long as this poor heart of mine holds life, I shall never love any one else. I am prosperous, rich, blessed with abundance —all shall be placed at her feet.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: You, Mr. Barry ! one of the wealthiest men in the colony, marry a person in her position! Remember what she is.

sp.speaker: Barry.
sp.p: I only remember what she was—a good, innocent girl. The man that deserts a suffering woman in the hour of need, is unworthy of the name he bears. I made her an offer before I left England—I will repeat it now, and restore her to freedom. Oh, that I could have induced her years ago to join her lot to mine, and shake off her wild attachment to the man she loved—a villain, unworthy of her—but she clung to him with all the ardour of a young, true heart. Where is she?

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: Walking in the woods, after her daily labour. She always walks alone, appearing to shun all society.

sp.speaker: Barry.
sp.p: Poor girl! she feels her situation, (distant thunder, rain.) A storm! We shall have the river rising rapidly. I must herd my cattle, or they'll be carried away by the floods. Bring Margaret to my farm, and tell her, from me, that she is mistress of John Barry's heart and fortune; and that the same love that prompted him to offer his hand to her in prosperity, does the same in adversity.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: A very extraordinary young man, that! Rich— respected, and good station, wanting to marry a person like Margaret—a prisoner! It's very odd! Merely because she was his first love. Lor, bless us! Men's first loves, and second loves, and last loves, are like the fashions—generally changed every month !

div.head: Scene III.—A close and cut Wood, with the Stage open, L., forming a ravine, over which is a stunted tree, the branches overhanging the ravine! Distant thunder, rain, lightning.
div.stage: Music.—Ben Luff, wild and haggard in his appearance, his beard long, hair matted, and his clothes in rags, crawls on, dejectedly, R.U.E.

sp.speaker: Luff.
sp.p: I can't stand up against this much longer! My glass is nearly run out. Starvation and fatigue have done their worst. A tough heart's softened like a woman's. I have had no rest or peace since I shot my messmate, Bill Laud. I can't forget the lad, though I escaped free. I can't run away from myself, he's always alongside, with his pale face, and bleeding wounds, (shudders.) I can't fly from him, he's ever on my track! After that night I took ship, and came out here to the New World, but it's no use, there's some'at here— (striking his breast.)—won't let me sleep or forget. I darn't ask for work, for fear of detection. The wild, outlandish country's my only chance. All this is along of that pale faced sweetheart of his. I only wish it had been her instead of Will I'd brought down. (thunder, &c.) My eyes! it does come down. The river's flooded already. I must climb one of these trees, and wait till daylight, or else I shall be grabbed by the wild beast or savages, and I haven't the heart to die now. (Music—He conceals himself in the bushes, L. U. E.—Lightning.)

div.stage: Margaret runs on, greatly alarmed, n., shading her eyes.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p:
I've missed the path to the farm, and there is no track to lead me out of this wood. What shall I do! How foolish to walk so far from home! (sighs.) Home! alas, my home is far
enough away. I shall never look on that any more. Endurance and repentance is all that's left me. (thunder.) How awfully the tempest rages! (loud cry without.—Margaret runs to the edge of the ravine, L., and looks down.) A man has fallen down the precipice! He clings to the bushes—if they prove weak, he is dashed to atoms ! I dare not look at the gulph. (Ben calls for help.) He must not perish without one effort to save him from death. Poor fellow! he stands as helpless as a child. (kneels over rock—calls to him.) Strive to gain the rock—there —there, and I will give you my hand. He rises! That's well done. Courage! another effort, and you're saved! Now climb holdly—'tis for life ! He does—(a branch heard to break—she screams and hides her face.) He is killed! No, no, he staggers again, brave fellow, (holds by the tree—the branches bend, and she extends her body over the ravine.) Take my hand—quick— quick! Think not of me—the branches may give way. Your hand—life depends on the grasp!

div.stage: Music.—Ben Luff's hands are seen—Margaret grasps them, and draws him gradually out of the ravine—he sinks on his knees forward, L. C.

sp.speaker: Luff.
sp.p: Thanks—thanks! I'm all right, and be d—d to it!

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: This is not the language of thanks to Providence, whose mercy spared you.

sp.speaker: Luff.
sp.p: (laughs wildly.) Spare me! What for? That I might bear more tortures—feel the bitter gnawings of hunger—to shun, and be shunned by my fellow men—to wander in these infernal woods, in companionship with beasts and savages.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Who are you ?

sp.speaker: Luff.
sp.p: A man. Once as brave a man as ever pulled a trigger—now worse than a woman at heart, girl!

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: What have you done to cause this change ?

sp.speaker: Luff.
sp.p: That, I'm ashamed of. I killed my messmate—not in a fair stand up fight, where life was opposed to life, but in the dark I stole upon him—dogged his steps, poor lad, and shot him when he most needed a hand to help him—but it was all along of her—curse her!

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Where did you commit this crime ?

sp.speaker: Luff.
sp.p: Over the seas, in England. I wish I'd given myself up to justice, but I had not courage. Poor Will!

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: (starts.) Did you say William ?

sp.speaker: Luff.
sp.p: To be sure I did. Will Laud!

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: (screams.) You—you are—

sp.speaker: Luff.
sp.p: Ben Luff, his—

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Murderer! The cruel murderer of an innocent, trusting man ! Wretch! expect no mercy at my hands. Fly, or I will give you up !

sp.speaker: Luff.
sp.p: You must catch me first. What is it to you ?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: What is it to me, villain ? Everything! My liberty and happiness died with him. I am Margaret.

sp.speaker: Luff.
sp.p: The devil you are! Then my revenge has come at last! I'll pay you off old scores. It was through you I and Bill quarrelled, (draws a knife.) I owe you some'at!

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Wretch ! Would you dare harm me ? Think of the crimes already on your head—repent, while you've time—

sp.speaker: Luff.
sp.p: Stuff! Palavering won't get you out of my clutches now. (approaching her.)

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Forbear! Is this the return for perilling my life to save yours?

sp.speaker: Luff.
sp.p: I don't vally that. You're the cause of all my hardships—here's payment for it!

div.stage: Music.—He advances towards Margaret—she flies from him— he pursues her to the ravine—they struggle—she screams for mercy—he forces her to the edge, dropping his knife— she, by a desperate effort, releases herself, and hurls him down picks up the knife, and stands in a fixed attitude, looking down—a wild cry, and stones are heard to fall.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: He is dashed to pieces! (stands in attitude—thunder and lightning. Closed in by

div.head: Scene IV.—A Jungle or Wood. Distant voices heard, r.

sp.speaker: Pegs.
sp.p: (without.) Step out, or we shall be washed away!

div.stage: Enter Pegs, dragging the Native in the net, R., followed by Pip and Sally—Pip carries the spear, and is crying.

sp.speaker: Pegs.
sp.p: Walk on ! We shall soon get to the farm. Once under cover, we shall be all right.

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: We shall be starved to death, like the two babes in the wood.

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.p: And there be no cock robins here to cover us—oh !

sp.speaker: Pegs.
sp.p: Courage, my bold Briton !

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.p: I bean't a bold Briton ! I be a soft 'un!

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: What's the use of driving that blackamoor creetur about with us?

sp.speaker: Pegs.
sp.p: Prudence, Mrs. Pip—prudence! We may want to eat him.

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: Ugh! I shall swoon away! Eat him !

sp.speaker: Pegs.
sp.p: Or stuff him—as the case may be. He'll fetch something, to stand at the door of a cigar shop in England. (thunder.) There it is again!

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: Here it is again, you mean! I'm drenched through and through! (a noise of Natives without.) The savages are coming again ! (frantic yells, r.)

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.p: It's that Day and Martin's relations coming to look after him! Let him go, Pegs—let him go!

div.stage: (they attempt to run out, but are stopped by Natives, from L. —the Captive is released from the net, and Pegs, Pip, and Sally placed in it.)

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.p: We're all caught in our own net, now!

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: Pity my youth, kind blackamoor gentlemen!

div.stage: (the Natives caper round them.)

sp.speaker: Pegs.
sp.p: We're all booked for Gravesend! Crying's no use. Prepare for a roast or a broil!

div.stage: (Natives drag them in the net—some of them have brought on sticks and a light—they fasten the net to a spear—place sticks round the Captives, and light them—they all scream out—the Natives yell)

sp.speaker: Shouts (without.)
sp.p: To the river—to the river—this way!

sp.speaker: Pegs.
sp.p: (shouts.) This way! Ulloa! Murder! Manslaughter!

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: Womanslaughter! (Natives appear alarmed.)

div.stage: Enter a party of Settlers, L.—the Natives fly rapidly, R.— the Captives are released.

sp.speaker: 1st Settler.
sp.p: How came you in their hands?

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.p: He did it all—that wicked Aldgate Pump—he brought us out!

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: And took us in—the false perjurer! Hanging's too good for him. We'll go back to our own country by the first ship.

sp.speaker: Pegs.
sp.p: Britons, countrymen, and lovers, hear me for my cause, and be silent that you may hear. 'Tis true I took this clodpate—

sp.speaker: 1st Settler.
sp.p: We can't listen to your nonsense. Lives are at stake —the river's overflowing, and carrying everything before it. Mr. Barry's farm will be washed away—perhaps his life lost! Come—come, boys!

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.p: Take us with you. We'll go to England again! Them horrible niggers may come back again, and—

sp.speaker: Pegs.
sp.p: Take my arm, ma'am—

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: If you come near me, I'll slap your face ! (hits him.)

sp.speaker: Pegs.
sp.p: A blow! Oh, ye thunders!

div.stage: Music.—Loud yell of the Natives, R.—they run off, L., nearly over each other.

div.head: Scene V.—An Immense Tract of Uncultivated Country, almost under water, from the river having burst its banks. The banks to L. elevated—in the R. U. E. of stage is a house nearly covered with water—trees are lying in the water, having been uprooted by its violence.
div.stage: Music.—When the scene opens, numbers of Persons are on the banks, L., moving to and fro—thunder, lightning, and rain—a boat is near the bank.

sp.speaker: 1st Settler.
sp.p: We've come too late! Nothing can save poor Barry and his people now !

sp.speaker: 2nd Settler.
sp.p: The river would swamp the best boat ever made.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. Palmer and Margaret, L.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Save them, if you are men! Do not let your fellow creatures perish without one effort to save them.

sp.speaker: 2nd Settler.
sp.p: It's useless. We dare not risk our lives.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: Will no one venture ?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Do not ask them. I'll go alone, and shame these men that dare not venture. The red blush will mantle on their cheeks when they see a helpless girl dare encounter what their manly courage shrunk from !

sp.speaker: 1st Settler.
sp.p: We can't risk our lives for nothing—we must be paid.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Shame upon you! Is this your humanity ? Does your heart teach you to sell your good deeds for gold ?

div.stage: Barry appears on the roof, with Two Women and Two Children, R.—waters fearfully agitated—almost concealing the house at times.

sp.speaker: Barry.
sp.p: (calling.) Help—help! for the love of Heaven!

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: Poor Barry!

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: His voice! Will you see him perish ? Cowards! Dastards! give me a rope, (snatches rope.) Learn your duty from me. (calls.) Courage—aid is near you—courage!

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: Margaret, your life will be lost!

sp.speaker: Settlers.
sp.p: Don't let her go !

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: I will—I will! I have no coward fears. My trust is in the power that rules the whirlwind and the storm!

div.stage: (runs off, L., and rows on L., in a boat conveying a rope—the boat is fearfully tossed about—rain, thunder, and lightning.)

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Huzza!

div.stage: (Margaret reaches the house, gives rope—it is held on and hauled to the roof—Barry jumps into Margaret's boat.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: They are saved !

div.stage: (Margaret and Barry assist the Females and Children into the boat, then row to bank L.—Barry takes Margaret in his arms.)

sp.speaker: Barry.
sp.p: My deliverer—my wife! Speak—speak—

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Yours—yours for ever !

div.stage: (the People on the bank shout at their escape—the house sinks under the water—thunder and lightning—the water is much agitated.—Picture formed.)
CURTAIN.
